{"step_by_step_thinking": "To determine the most common cyst associated with adjoining vital teeth, we need to consider the characteristics and prevalence of each option. 

A. Dentigerous cyst: This cyst is associated with the crown of an unerupted or impacted tooth. It is commonly found in the mandibular third molar region and is usually associated with non-vital teeth. 

B. Globulomaxillary cyst: This cyst is typically found between the maxillary lateral incisor and canine. It is not commonly associated with adjoining vital teeth. 

C. Periapical cyst: This cyst is associated with the apex of a non-vital tooth. It is the most common cyst found in the jaws, but it is not specifically associated with adjoining vital teeth. 

D. Lateral periodontal cyst: This cyst is found along the lateral aspect of the root of a vital tooth. It is the least common cyst among the options provided. 

Based on the information provided, the most common cyst associated with adjoining vital teeth is the Dentigerous cyst (option A).", "answer_choice": "A"}
